Matt Troost joined the farm-to-table movement while working at the prestigious Montagna at The Little Nell in Aspen CO. There he learned artisan crafts such as curing meats and making cheese. After four years he made his move to Chicago and spent time at The Peninsula Hotel and then Fianco as executive chef. In 2010, his dream became reality when he opened the Chicago favorite Three Aces, known for it’s funky, low-key vibe and outstanding burgers.

Since then he’s won the Golden Rasher at the 2012 Baconfest and the People’s Choice at the 2012 Chicago Gourmet Hamburger Hop. Matt continues to push the envelope with interesting combinations rooted in comfort food while still staying true to local purveyors. His philosophy: “What grows together, goes together.”

Matt's restaurant

Three Aces
Chef Troost’s recipe

The Spice Is Right Burger

keep it moist

Consider where your moisture is coming from. Buns are dry and so is lean or well-cooked hamburger. So lean towards a melty cheese vs. a drier one. Aioli, mayo and tomatoes also add moisture.

bacon jam

Matt developed bacon jam as a spread because he wanted there to be bacon in every bite. “Often, when bacon isn’t crispy enough, you pull a whole slice out of the hamburger on your first bite. So while the first bite is wonderful, the rest of burger has little bacon flavor. Bacon jam solves that problem” Just grind some bacon, cook it down and add a little vinegar, wine and a fair amount of sugar. Use it as a spread on the bottom bun of the burger.

gratuitous seasoning

The most important part of the burger is the seasoning. Go for some nice (and heavy) salting and peppering. You only get the opportunity to season the burger once and you want to make sure you do it right.

Q & A

Which Mariano’s do you shop?

I shop at Mariano’s West Loop store on Halstead.

You’re known for your burgers. What do you look for in ground beef?

I look for fat content. Fat is where the flavor is, so I stay away from lean meats. I don’t hold back when I cook or eat.

Do you personally visit the local farm your meat is sourced from?

Most of our meats are from Slagel Family Farm in Fairbury and I’ve been down to see the farm and have actually cooked a couple dinners down there with them.

Where did “farm to plate” come from?

It’s an old world concept that a lot of restaurants are trying to get back into. It’s healthier and you get a higher quality product.

What word best describes Mariano’s meat department?

Vast. Between the cured meats and the fresh meats, there’s just so much to choose from.

What’s your favorite bar snack?

Big, soft pretzels.

Who were you inspired by to begin cooking?

My mom. She taught me how to make coffee cake when I was really young.

What are some unexpected meats you can use for a burger?

I’ve used ground duck. I’ve done ground pork. We did a lamb burger called “Mary Got Hungry.” (note: he’s not joking)

How do you personally take your burger?

Medium rare.

Your menu is adventurous. How can grillers at home keep things interesting? Is there one simple thing?

Too many grillers under-season their burgers. Season generously. And ketchup and mustard are fine, but aioli is easy to make and it adds great flavor.

What are some of your favorite burger toppings?

A good sharp cheese –cheddar or blue, then a little bit of something green, an onion and a little mayo or aioli. I’m real simple with my burgers.

What do you look for in a hamburger bun?

I like all different buns – pretzel buns, brioche, potato buns – it all depends on the type of burger you’re making.

The local brew scene has exploded. What in your opinion is the best in Chicago?

(note: Matt didn’t want to answer – he has a lot of friends in the brewing biz and didn’t want to miss out on a free pint by leaving anybody out)
